column1: A subdural hematoma is more common in the elderly because of normal brain shrinkage that occurs with aging.

Risks include: - Long-term heavy alcohol use - Long-term use of aspirin, anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen, or blood thinning (anticoagulant) medication such as warfarin - Diseases associated with reduced blood clotting - Head injury - Old age

However, depending on the size of the hematoma and where it presses on the brain, any of the following symptoms may occur: - Confusion or coma - Decreased memory - Difficulty speaking or swallowing - Difficulty walking - Drowsiness - Headache - Seizures - Weakness or numbness of arms, legs, face
The goal of treatment is to control symptoms and reduce or prevent permanent damage to the brain.
Anticonvulsant medications such as carbamazepine, lamotrigine or levetiracetam may be used to control or prevent seizures.
This may include drilling small holes in the skull to relieve pressure and allow blood and fluids to be drained.
Large hematomas or solid blood clots may need to be removed through a larger opening in the skull (craniotomy).
Chronic subdural hematomas that cause symptoms usually do not heal on their own over time.
